instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.BLK_PWM: What is BLK_PWM? BLK_PWM is a typo of BKL_PWM. When you see BLK_PWM assume the poster meant to type BKL_PWM. BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message: Hey, I just got in a 15" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no data or backlight. but has a good chime.  i pulled the volts of all the probes to the lcd connector but am spending to much time trying to see what volts are wrong if any.  any help in reading my results would be great! Thought it might have been the <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> but im getting 3.4v at the lvds so i factored that out

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message: You have 30V on the backlight pins 38,39,40 so there must be backlight and an image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message: Okay,  I still have no image so perhaps its the lvds connector? i have tried it on 3 other screens with the same results. but from screen to screen i get dif results. some screens give me a few colored lines down it.  but still no image or backlight. plugged into the external monitor i get an image.  any  thoughts here? I ran out of lvds connectors so until  those come in i cant test that theory

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message:
Does it boot into OSX on an external screen? 
Is <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> high?
30V on backlight pins must mean there is backlight. Check <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message:
It appears it does but i cannot get the main screen on the external and it seems pretty glitchy not sure if that is the hdmi port or the board.    

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.1v open but is also 3.1v closed, if i understand correctly that should be dif when the lid is closed? 

<SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> IS 3.1v AND <SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL> IS 2.92v

Also i noticed wile i was testing probes, (its possible that i touched 2 parts together with my probe) That the screen backlight had come on but quickly turned off. (also note all screens im using to test are confirmed working)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a  NO IMAGE OR BACKLIGHT
threads.message: If this does not fully boot into OSX it probably is a bad GPU. Take it to Apple for a free repair!
